questions.text: 1. Which of the following imaging modalities is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The imaging modalities contraindicated in pregnancy among the given options is CT Scan. 

CT is a high-resolution technique using x-rays to generate cross-sectional images of any area of the body. It is associated with high radiation doses. Hence, CT scan is avoided during pregnancy due to the potential adverse effects of radiation on the fetus. 

Other options:

Option A: MRI is useful for high soft tissue contrast and acquisition of images. It is devoid of any ionizing radiation and found to have no fetal harmful effect at any gestational age. However, the gadolinium contrast MRI in pregnancy should be used with caution as gadolinium crosses the placenta.

Option C: Ultrasound is the most commonly used imaging tool in obstetrics. There is no documented harmful effects to the fetus from diagnostic ultrasound. 

Option D: Color Doppler is based on the principle of Doppler frequency shift. Doppler ultrasound is used to measure the speed at which blood is moving within a vessel. The effects of ultrasound on tissues are: temperature elevation, formation of microbubbles and cavitation. However, there is no clear evidence till date that diagnostic ultrasound examination during pregnancy is harmful. Ultrasound should be done with shortest duration possible to avoid unnecessary exposure, especially with the Doppler.

questions.text: 2. All of the following cause fetal bradycardia during labour except:
questions.solution:
Maternal fever causes fetal tachycardia, and not bradycardia. 

Causes of fetal bradycardia (FHR<110bpm):

* Fetal hypoxia due to maternal or fetal causes (eg. placental abruption)

* Fetal sepsis

* Fetal anomalies

* Drugs to mother, e.g., pethidine, antihypertensives (methyldopa, propranolol), MgSO4

* Use of local anesthetic drugs or epidural analgesia

* Fetal congenital heart block or conduction defects

* Maternal hypoglycemia and hypothermia

Low baseline heart rate is also seen in fetal head compression from occiput posterior or transverse positions during second-stage labor.

Prolonged deceleration is seen in placental abruption which is the abrupt decrease in fetal heart rate ( of 15 bpm or more) to levels below the baseline and it lasts >3 min but <10 min. It can also be seen in uterine rupture, cord prolapse and uterine hyperstimulation.

Causes of fetal tachycardia (FHR>160bpm):

* Maternal fever (most common cause)

* Drugs to mother - Eg. Isoxsuprine and ritodrine used to inhibit preterm labor and vagolytics like atropine.

* Maternal hyperthyroidism and metabolic acidemia

* Infection

* Anemia

questions.text: 3. A 28-year-old woman who has been breastfeeding her 6-month-old baby presents with tenderness and mild erythema of the breast. She was breastfeeding normally. Imaging shows a hypoechoic, irregular mass. Core biopsy shows cystic spaces surrounded by neutrophils. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative organism in this clinical context of a breastfeeding woman with breast tenderness, erythema, and a hypoechoic irregular mass on imaging, plus histology showing cystic spaces surrounded by neutrophils, is characteristic of granulomatous mastitis, which can be caused by Corynebacterium kroppenstedtii. 

Granulomatous mastitis is a benign, self-limiting, inflammatory breast disease that was earlier considered idiopathic. A distinct histological pattern, termed cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis (CNGM), is believed to be caused by Corynebacterium kroppenstedtii. This condition primarily occurs in young women who are parous, typically manifesting within the initial few years postpartum. It manifests as one or more inflammatory breast masses (central or peripheral), which may or may not progress to form an abscess. It may be associated with skin ulceration, nipple retraction, sinus formation, peau d’orange, and axillary lymphadenopathy. 

A needle biopsy of a solid mass establishes the diagnosis of IGM. Histologically, CNGM often shows lipogranulomas with cystic spaces and neutrophilic infiltrates. In symptomatic patients and in those with infection, treatment with NSAIDs and antibiotics with or without drainage is indicated. In cases of persistent symptoms or progression, treatment with prednisolone (oral or topical) with or without methotrexate has helped in regression of IGM. A major milk duct excision is indicated in patients with a mammary duct fistula. Excision of chronic abscess cavities is performed in patients with recurrence.

Other options:

Option A: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a close differential, but histology should show caseating granulomas, which is not the case here. However, to rule out TB, along with histopathology, evidence on imaging, microbiological analysis, and GeneXpert is required to establish a diagnosis. 

Option C: Cryptococcus neoformans is more common in immunocompromised patients, shows yeast on biopsy, and does not typically cause neutrophil-rich cystic lesions.

Option D: Corynebacterium minutissimum usually causes erythrasma, a superficial skin infection, and not deep granulomatous mastitis.

questions.text:
4. A woman presents to you for a routine pap smear. Arrange the steps involved in the correct order:

1. Lithotomy position 2. Per speculum examination 3. Scraping of cells using Ayer's spatula 4. Per vaginal examination
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the procedure involved in the collection of a sample for a pap smear is 1, 2, 3. 

The Pap/Papanicolaou smear is used for screening cervical neoplasia.

Procedure:

* The patient is put in a lithotomy position with the labia are parted (Statement 1)

* Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is gently introduced with the use of lubricant or jelly (Statement 2)

* The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula (Statement 3)

* Endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush

* Samples are spread separately on two different glass slides

* The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol

* Stained with Pap stain or short stain

Per vaginal examination (Statement 4) is not part of the routine pap smear procedure. In fact, the Pap smear should be obtained before vaginal examination, because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report, lubricant may prevent detection of organisms and any vaginal bleeding during examination may preclude a proper visualization of the cervix.

questions.text: 5. A primigravida came for regular antenatal care in her first trimester. She has no complaints of dysuria or increased frequency, but her urine routine reveals ≥ 10^5 CFU/mL E. coli. Her urine culture was done again and showed the same organism. What is the most common complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition described is asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy, which is defined as the presence of ≥ 10⁵ CFU/mL of bacteria in the urine without urinary symptoms. The most common complication of untreated asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy is preterm labour.

Asymptomatic bacteriuria refers to persistent, actively multiplying bacteria within the urinary tract in asymptomatic women. It is defined as one or more bacterial species that have a count ≥105 colony-forming units/mL determined by urine culture of a voided specimen. It is more common in women with diabetes.

If asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) is not treated, approximately 25 percent of affected women will develop symptomatic infection during pregnancy. If not treated, it might progress to pyelonephritis and can have increased risks of low-birthweight neonates, preterm delivery, pregnancy-associated hypertension, and anaemia.

E.coli is the most common species isolated in pregnant women. Empirical oral treatment for 10 days with nitrofurantoin 100 mg at bedtime is usually effective.

Other options:

Option A: Asymptomatic bacteriuria is not significantly associated with first-trimester miscarriage. Most miscarriages in early pregnancy are due to genetic or anatomical causes, not subclinical UTIs.

Option C: Fetal hypoxia typically results from placental or umbilical cord problems and is not a known direct consequence of asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy.

Option D: Chorioamnionitis is more commonly due to ascending infections from the genital tract and prolonged rupture of membranes, not from asymptomatic bacteriuria.

questions.text: 6. A woman came for preconception counselling who has a h/o epilepsy and is taking epileptic drugs, which anti epileptic drug is highly teratogenic?
questions.solution:
Valproate is an anti-epileptic drug that is highly teratogenic to the fetus.

Valproate is an anti-epileptic medication. It is also used as a mood stabilizer in manic episodes as well as in bipolar disorder. The repetitive firing caused by depolarization of cortical or spinal cord neurons is inhibited by valproate. It also prolongs the sodium channel inactivation. It can stimulate the activity of the GABA synthetic enzyme, glutamic acid decarboxylase, and inhibit GABA degradative enzymes.

It is highly teratogenic and can cause congenital anomalies like neural tube defects (spina bififda), clefts, and cardiac anomalies. The intelligence quotient score of school-going children who were exposed in utero to valproate is found reduced. It also contributes to poor cognitive development in children. Folate supplementation reduces the chances of neural tube defects. 

The side effects of valproate (mnemonic: VALPROATE)

* Vomiting

* Alopecia

* Liver toxicity

* Pancreatitis

* Rash

* Obesity

* Anorexia

* Teratogenicity

* Oedema

The images below show a baby and a USG with spinal bifida:





Other options: 

Option C: Oxcarbazepine can also cause fetal hydantoin syndrome and spina bifida, but the risk of teratogenicity is significantly lower than valproate. 

Option B and D: Lamotrigine and levetiracetam are considered safer anti-epileptic drugs in pregnancy, with low teratogenic risk when used at appropriate doses.

Pearl PM2022: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
ACE inhibitors and ARBs

Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, irreversible renal failure
Carbimazole and Methimazole  

Choanal atresia, aplasia cutis, tracheoesophageal fistula and fetal goiter
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text:
7. Which of the following are acceptable times for the insertion of a Copper IUD?

1. Immediately postpartum 2. Within 48 hours postpartum 3. Until day 5-7 of menstrual cycle 4. Within 7 days before next menstrual cycle
questions.solution:
The acceptable times for the insertion of a copper IUD are immediately postpartum, within 48 hours postpartum and until day 5-7 of menstrual cycle, but not within 7 days before next menstrual cycle. 

The different timings for IUCD insertion are as follows:

* Post-placental: Can be done immediately, within 10 minutes after expulsion of the placenta following a vaginal delivery. (Statement 1)

* Intracesarean: Insertion during cesarean delivery, after removal of the placenta and before closure of the uterine incision.

* Within 48 hours after delivery: Should be done before the patient is discharged from the hospital. (Statement 2)

* Extended postpartum: Any time after 6 weeks postpartum.

* Interval insertion: Refers to insertion during the interconceptional period. It is preferable to insert the IUCD 2–3 days after menstruation ends. However, insertion during the menstrual phase is also safe and offers certain advantages (e.g., open cervical canal, distended uterine cavity, reduced cramping). Therefore, insertion until day 5–7 of the menstrual cycle is acceptable, as the likelihood of pregnancy is low during this time. (Statement 3)

* Postabortal: Can be inserted immediately after pregnancy termination by suction and evacuation or dilatation and evacuation, or following a spontaneous abortion.

* As emergency contraception: May be inserted up to 5 days following unprotected intercourse.

However, insertion within 7 days before the next expected menstrual cycle is not advisable. This is because ovulation may have already occurred, and pregnancy cannot be confidently ruled out, increasing the risk of inserting the IUD in an early, undiagnosed pregnancy (Statement 4).

Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) are a safe, effective and reversible method of contraception. The different types of IUCD are shown below:



Pearl PM2328: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

* Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)

* Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate

* Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)

* Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women

* Norethisterone 350 μg

* Norgestrel 75 μg

* Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg

* Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results

* Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone

* Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia

* Post-coital pills or interceptive

* Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart

* Mifepristone 10-600 mg

* Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse

* Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse

* GnRH agonists  

* CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

* Progesterone only injectables

* DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months

* NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months

* Combined injectables

* Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg

* Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

* Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg

* Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

* Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day

* Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week

* Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

Pearl PM2096: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations


Pearl PM1785: Methods of contraceptions

Methods Advantages Disadvantages
Barrier
  • Prevents STD, HIV
  • The incidence of Ca cervix reduced
  • Effective if used properly
  • No contraindication use
  • Cumbersome
  •  Coital dependent
  •  Short term
  •  High failure rate
Lactation
  • Beneficial to the newborn
  • Contraceptive action (non-ovulatlon) 6 months
 Short-term benefit
IUCD
  • Long-term use
  • Effective
  • Coital Independent
 Side effects
• Failure rate 1-3%
• Contraindicated In few
Hormones Effective 99-100% long-term use of beneficial effects
of OC coital independent		 Side effects
• Not used during lactation
• Contraindicated In few
• Requires Surgery for implantation
Surgery Permanent and effective Surgical complications surgery required.
• Not suited in low parity women
Postcoital Effective 95-98% short-term use Failure in 1-5%
Not used as contraceptives

questions.text: 8. The use of MgSO4 has all of the following benefits except
questions.solution:
The use of MgSO4 provide neuroprotection for the foetus, can prevent seizures and prevent placental abruption. Increase in renal perfusion is not a proven effect of MgSO4. 

Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4) is shown to have anticonvulsant and neuroprotective effects by the following mechanisms: 

* It reduces presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate

* It blocks the glutamatergic N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptors

* It can potentiate  adenosine action

* It improves calcium buffering by mitochondria

* It blocks calcium entry via voltage-gated channels

Magnesium sulphate is the drug of choice in the management of eclampsia to control convulsions.It can be used to prevent seizures and can signifcantly lower risk of eclampsia. Even the rates of placental abruption are seen to decrease in women who recieved magnesium sulpate.

It can also have a protective effect against the development of cerebral palsy in very-low birthweight newborns. Hence it is also used for neuroprotection for the fetus less than 32 weeks.

Impaired renal function is a contraindication for MgSO4. However, its effect on renal perfusion is not entirely clear. Some studies report it can decrease renal plasma flow or glomerular filtration rate, while others suggest it may enhance perfusion and exert renoprotective effects, depending on context and dosage. Among the given options, the role of magnesium sulphate in increasing renal perfusion is not well proven and hence, is the correct answer here.

questions.text: 9. Which of the following uterine-stimulating drugs is not used in the management of PPH?
questions.solution:
Dinoprostone is not used in the management of post-partum hemorrhage (PPH). 

Dinoprostone is a PGE2 analogue which is primarily important for cervical ripening. Intracervical application of dinoprostone (0.5 mg) gel is the gold standard for cervical ripening. It can also be used in the form of tablet or controlled release pessary.

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) defined as the excessive bleeding following delivery (>500 mL in vaginal delivery or >1000 mL in cesarean delivery) accompanied by signs and symptoms of hypovolemia.  Atonicity of the uterus is the commonest cause of postpartum hemorrhage.

For the management of PPH, Oxytocin 20-40 units in 1 L of normal saline IV is started at the rate of 20-40 drops per minute immediately. Carbetocin, a longer acting oxytocin derivative is found (100 µg) to be as effective as oxytocin infusion.

In refractory cases,

* Injection 15 Methyl PGF2α 250 µg IM in the deltoid muscle can be given every 15 minutes (up to maximum of 2 mg) or,

* Misoprostol (PGE1) 1000 mg per rectum can also be given.

questions.text:
10. A 19-year-old girl presents with irregular menstrual cycles. According to the Modified Rotterdam criteria, which of the following are diagnostic for PCOS?

1. Obesity 2. Delayed periods 3. Hirsutism 4. Insulin resistance
questions.solution:
According to the Modified Rotterdam criteria, delayed periods and hirsutism are diagnostic for PCOS. 

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. For the diagnosis of PCOS, the modified Rotterdam criteria are generally followed. It states that at least two of three criteria should be present. These criteria are as follows:

* Irregular menstrual cycles characterised by oligomenorrhoea of cycles >35 days apart or <8 menses a year or amenorrhoea or anovulation  infertility

* Hyperandrogenism which can be clinically detected as hirsutism / acne with a modified Ferriman–Gallwey score of ≥4 to ≥8 or biochemically detected by elevated total or free testosterone. DHEAS (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate)and ANSD (androstenedione) can be consdered. 

* Ultrasound finding of enlarged ovaries with ovarian volume of more than 10 mm3 with 12 or more small follicles, each 2-9 mm in size, placed peripherally. ≥20 follicles per ovary in either ovary or ≥10 cm3 ovarian volume

The new International Evidence-based Guidelines for the assessment and management of polycystic ovary syndrome 2023 supersede the previous USG recommendations of the Rotterdam criteria. According to this guideline, these three factors should be considered accurate ultrasound markers for PCOS in adults:

* Follicle number per ovary (FNPO) ≥ 20 in at least one ovary 

* If an accurate follicle count is not possible: Follicle number per cross-section (FNPS) ≥ 10 in at least one ovary, or 

* Ovarian volume (OV) ≥ 10 ml

The ultrasound image below shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery:



Pearl PM1151: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

* Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.

* LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.

* Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.

* Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)

* Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor

* DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated

* DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour

* Serum SHBG is reduced.

* Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.

* Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance

* Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases

* Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases

* Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)

* 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

* Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Pearl PM1152: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene


Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: 11. A 30-year-old woman presents for infertility workup. Laparoscopic Chromopertubation shows normal tubes and dye spills freely. What is the most likely cause of infertility?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infertility due to PCOS and the image shows bilateral enlarged ovaries with a smooth and thickened capsule on laparoscopy. 

In PCOS, macroscopicaly both ovaries are enlarged. The ovary shows a thick white capsule of tunica albuginea. The ovarian surface may be lobulated but the peritoneal surface is free of adhesions. Multiple cysts ( 12 or more) of 2-9 mm size are located peripherally along the surface of the ovary giving it a 'necklace' appearance on ultrasound. These are persistent atretic follicles. Theca-cell hyperplasia and stromal hyperplasia account for the increase in the size of the ovary which amounts to more than 10 cm3 in volume.

As per the new International Evidence-based Guidelines for the assessment and management of polycystic ovary syndrome 2023, these three factors should be considered accurate ultrasound markers for PCOS in adults:

* Follicle number per ovary (FNPO) ≥ 20 in at least one ovary 

* If an accurate follicle count is not possible: Follicle number per cross-section (FNPS) ≥ 10 in at least one ovary, or 

* Ovarian volume (OV) ≥ 10 ml

Laparoscopy is reserved for a therapeutic purpose. ln most cases diagnosis can be confirmed on ultrasound.

Other options:

Option A: A tubo-ovarian mass (usually from infection or chronic inflammation) would likely distort pelvic anatomy and obstruct the tubes, and dye would not spill freely during chromopertubation.

Option B: Most ovarian cysts, especially functional or benign types, are typically unilateral and don’t typically cause the bilateral enlargement with thickened capsules seen in PCOS. Besides, PCOS is a leading and more common cause of infertility than ovarian cysts.

Option D: Endometriosis often presents with pelvic adhesions, endometriotic implants, or endometriomas, which would be visible during laparoscopy. The smooth ovarian surface and absence of lesions point against it.

questions.text: 12. Under the MTP Act of 2021, permission of 2 Registered medical practitioners to terminate a pregnancy is required when the gestational age is ____
questions.solution:
Under the MTP Act of 2021, permission of 2 RMPs (registered medical practitioners) is required to terminate a pregnancy when the gestational age is 20-24 weeks.

As per the Amendement to MTP Act, 2021, termination is permitted up to 24 weeks of pregnancy. Opinion of one RMP for MTP up to 20 weeks is needed. Pregnancy beyond 20 weeks needs opinions of two RMPs.

Beyond 24 weeks, pregnancy termination can be done for cases of substantial fetal abnormalities, as diagnosed and decided by the Medical Board which consists of :

* Gynaecologist

* Paediatrician

* Radiologist 

* Any member appointed by the Government

Pearl PM2131: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

* Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother

* Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure

* Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest

* Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

* Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.

* MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.

* The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

* Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion

* 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion

* For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

* Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations

* Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)

* At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: 13. A 60-year-old woman presented with abdominal swelling, early satiety, and pelvic discomfort. CA 125 was 990 U/L. On examination fluid wave was present, and a pelvic mass was felt. Ultrasound revealed multilocular solid components in an adnexal mass bilaterally. CECT showed ascites and omental caking. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this 60 year old woman is serous cystadenocarcinoma.

Her symptoms of abdominal swelling, early satiety, and pelvic discomfort are classic for advanced ovarian malignancy. The presence of a fluid wave suggests ascites, and the detection of a pelvic mass on examination further supports an ovarian origin.

A markedly elevated CA-125 level of 990 U/L is strongly indicative of epithelial ovarian cancer, particularly the serous subtype, which is the most common and typically presents with high CA-125 levels. Ultrasound findings of bilateral multilocular solid adnexal masses, and contrast-enhanced CT showing both ascites and omental caking are hallmarks of peritoneal carcinomatosis often seen in advanced serous carcinoma. 

Other options: 

Option A: Granulosa cell tumor are sex cord-stromal tumors that are usually unilateral. They are hormonally active and often produce estrogen, leading to symptoms such as abnormal uterine bleeding or endometrial hyperplasia, which are not seen in this patient. Additionally, granulosa cell tumors rarely cause massive ascites or omental caking, and they do not typically result in such a high CA-125 level as seen here (990 U/L). 

Option B: Endometroid adenofibroma is a rare and benign tumor that does not typically produce symptoms like abdominal distension, early satiety, or pelvic discomfort. These tumors are usually small, unilateral, and typically doesn't present with ascites, elevated CA-125, or peritoneal spread. Bilateral solid masses and omental caking are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

Option C: Mucinous cystadenoma is a benign epithelial ovarian tumor that is usually large and unilateral, often presenting as a multilocular cystic mass. However, it typically does not cause ascites, omental caking, or elevated CA-125 levels, all of which are present in this case. While it may cause abdominal discomfort due to its size, the presence of bilateral solid components, a markedly elevated tumor marker, and evidence of peritoneal spread are more indicative of a malignant process, making mucinous cystadenoma an unlikely diagnosis.

Note: Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma is a malignant form and behaves differently from mucinous cystadenoma.

Pearl PM1433: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

* Serous tumors

* Mucinous tumors

* Endometrioid tumors

* Clear cell 

* Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)

* Seromucinous

* Undifferentiated carcinoma

II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:

* Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor

* Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor

* Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

* Dysgerminoma

* Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)

* Embryonal carcinoma

* Polyembryoma

* Non-gestational choriocarcinoma

* Teratoma (Mature/immature)

* Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

* Pure

* Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary VI. Miscellaneous tumors VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors VIII. Tumor-like conditions

Pearl PM1872: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell


Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

* D: Dysgerminoma

* P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)

* L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)
